Thanks for joining us.

No spaces.
Just nprnewsandnotes.org.

Tomorrow we come to you live from South Carolina, home to this week's Democratic presidential primary.
I'm Tony Cox and this is NEWS & NOTES.
This is DAY TO DAY.
I'm Alex Chadwick.
I'm Madeleine Brand.
In few minutes, who you need to see if you want to get elected in California.
First, before California and the rest of Super Tuesday, there are other places to campaign: South Carolina for the Democrats and next week's big Florida primary.
Joining us is NPR's senior Washington editor, Ron Elving.
Ron, welcome back and the Democrats turned out really in big numbers in Nevada for the first caucus in that state than ever really mattered.
What does Hillary Clinton's win there tell us?
It tells us that she can battle back from a disadvantage.
She didn't get the big union endorsements that she wanted, Obama did, and yet Hillary came back and split the union vote with him right down the middle.
It tells us she's more appealing to Hispanics than he is.
She won two-thirds of those votes.
It tells us that she has a problem with African-American voters, because she only got about 20 percent of that vote.
But at the same time, Barack Obama, while he was essentially the loser on the day, got as many and perhaps one more delegate out of the state than she did.
It was a closer contest than it may have appeared initially.

There is another Democratic debate in South Carolina tonight, Ron, and I expect Senator Obama may be speaking sharply as he has been over the last 24 hours about Senator Clinton, and especially about her husband.
Yes, Bill Clinton has become the designated attacker for the Clinton camp.
He's good at the role, and of course in this particular case if there's blowback, it comes to him more than to his wife, the candidate.
So that works even better for him.

You know, this debate that was on Martin Luther King Day, and I think an awful lot of the questions are going to reflect that, it's co-sponsored by the Congressional Black Caucus, and that's going to put a certain amount of pressure on Barack Obama.
Barack Obama is currently leading overwhelmingly among African-Americans in South Carolina, and they are half the voting base there.
But at the same time Barack Obama does not want to become exclusively the black candidate.
He doesn't want to be like Jesse Jackson in the 1980s, great to win in southern primaries, not so great in the rest of the country; not necessarily the way to win in the fall.
And Barack Obama's been focused from the beginning on being a candidate who could transcend race and win in the general election.
Let's switch to the Republicans, Ron, Senator John McCain winning in South Carolina.
Now everyone goes to Florida.
Indeed, everyone goes to Florida.
This is a traffic jam.
Rudy Giuliani had the state almost to himself for several weeks, and that's where he camped out.
He decided not to compete up north; just go for the former New Yorkers and all the other Floridians he might very well be able to nail down while the other candidates were absent.

Now everybody else is coming down to join him, John McCain with his South Carolina momentum, Mitt Romney with his Nevada and Michigan momentum, and still Mike Huckabee, who's been running a strong candidacy even though he hasn't been winning since Iowa.
He's got a big natural appeal to evangelicals in Florida; he's going to pull a lot of those votes, as he did in South Carolina.
So he's right in the hunt.
And you've still got the question marks over Fred Thompson.
Does he compete at all or does he drop out this week?
And Ron Paul, who is still a real candidate to five to 10 percent of the Republicans and in Florida, that could keep anybody from looking too terribly impressive.
Ron, let me tell something.

Earlier today I went and back through conversations that we've had with you in the past looking for a little clip of tape in which you said after Super Tuesday it's all over, but in fact you said back in November, maybe Super Tuesday is not going to solve things and maybe things will go on.
I was surprised that you are right back then and you look more right now.
I mean, this contest - boy, it's - I thought things were going to be over in two weeks.
Well, on the Democratic side, we may have two people slugging it out for quite a long period of time, although after Super Tuesday, February 5th, one of the two may be in a dominant position.
On the Republican side, no one is emerging.
Florida, in a sense, is a microcosm right now for the whole Republican Party.
You have four different candidates - Giuliani, Romney, McCain and Huckabee - all clustered right around 20 percent.
Nobody more than two points up or two points down.

That is a formula for an extended primary season, a delight for journalists, a delight for political observers, but not necessarily for the Republican Party, which usually prefers to consolidate its forces behind one nominee as early as possible.
Senior Washington editor Ron Elving, Ron The Right Elving.
Ron, thanks again.
Thank you, Alex.
OK, if you're looking for a cheaper health insurance than you can currently find on the individual market, a whole host of new options will become available starting tomorrow.
This is due to a change the Trump administration is making to insurance regulations.
But buyer beware - with lower prices come fewer benefits.
Here's NPR's Alison Kodjak.
That's Doug Badger, a visiting fellow at the conservative Heritage Foundation in Washington.
Moreover, the government has been charging utilities and their customers a fee to pay for a permanent waste dump.
David Wright, head of the National Association of Regulatory Utility Commissioners, says it's a rip-off.
They have chosen not to do anything.
The federal government has our money; we have their waste.
Wright says the court ruling in Washington is one development where environmentalists and utilities can agree.
The fact that we're finally getting some movement and recognition in the court system, is movement - and I think it's a positive development.
The appeals court says NRC must do an environmental assessment of all that waste.
It did not, however, set a due date.
Christopher Joyce, NPR News.
(SOUNDBITE OF MUSIC)
It's MORNING EDITION from NPR News.
Good morning.
I'm Steve Inskeep.
And I'm David Greene.
If you believe the Federal Reserve chairman, the long-term prospects for the U.S.
economy are still good.
The question President Obama faces tonight is how to get employers hiring more quickly in the short term, that is to say now.
It's a key economic question and also a key political question, since the president and most of the members of Congress he will address face reelection campaigns a little more than a year from now.
White House officials have been asking what could help the economy and also what might pass Congress in a bitterly partisan year.
We start our coverage with NPR's Scott Horsley.
President Obama hopes to create a new sense of urgency with his speech tonight.
Months of slow job growth have turned to no job growth, while the government was preoccupied with spending cuts.
With unemployment stuck above nine percent, Mr. Obama told supporters this week Americans can't wait on Washington any longer.
The time for action is now.
(Soundbite of cheering)
No more manufactured crises.
No more games.
Now is not the time for the people you sent to Washington to worry about their jobs.
Now is the time for them to worry about your jobs.
(Soundbite of cheering)
Certainly Americans are worried.
Consumer confidence fell sharply last month, along with confidence in the president's economic stewardship.
Mr. Obama will try to turn that around tonight.
But political analyst Jack Pitney of Claremont McKenna College says it won't be easy.
The stakes are high and the chips are of dubious value.

The president knows that he's going to have a very difficult time getting his plan through Congress and even if it does get through Congress, there's no guarantee it will have the kind of effect that he's hoping for.
The White House has been careful not to promise any particular payoff from the president's jobs proposal.
But economic advisor Gene Sperling says the plan is designed to include strong, fast-acting medicine.
What will be very clear is that it would have a meaningful impact on creating jobs over the next 12 to 18 months.
The plan is expected to include a combination of new and extended tax cuts, new spending on public works projects, and assistance for those who've been out of work a long time.
The White House will try to paint Congressional opponents of the package as indifferent to the nation's economic suffering.
But Pitney says the Administration is still dogged by the controversy that surrounds its early stimulus effort.
Many argue that it kept the recession from getting even worse, kept the unemployment rate from going even higher.
But the perception among many people in the general public is that it didn't have the kind of effect that the president advertised.
A lot of people will be listening to this speech and saying, you tried this before.
It didn't work then.
Why would it work now?
To be fair, the economy did start growing soon after the stimulus kicked in, and the recent slowdown in hiring came after most of the stimulus was exhausted.
Still, the White House has made little headway with that argument.

And former administration economist Jared Bernstein, who's now with the Center on Budget and Policy Priorities, says for much of the last year promoting jobs took a back seat as official Washington focused on cutting the deficit.
